advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 6000 MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> WE HAVE A NEW APPROACH TO DISTRIBUTED PROCESSING THAT WORKS <br><br> Already implemented are electronic mail, word processing, complete cost accounting with inventory control and more. The secret is a new technology called Functionally Structured Distribution (FSD). At last, a system to organize and manage distributed processing applications that is really up and running. FSD technology is especially applicable to installa­tions that require:<br> • Unlimited expandability supporting extremely large data bases and terminals in many cities.<br> • User-friendly software easily programmed in high level languages (COBOL, FORTRAN, and BASIC)<br> • System reliability (due to distributed hardware) while maintaining multiple levels of data security.<br> • Compatibility with existing mainframes and networks (including the Bell System). <br><br> We are presently installing Billings 6000 Computer Systems which take full advantage of distributed processing utilizing FSD technology. The 6000 Computer supports multiple hard disk drives with capacities of up to 64 Mbytes (formatted), streaming tapes for backup, auto-dial modems (2400 baud synchronous) for communications, and flexible disk drives for smaller installations.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #7 </strong></font><br><blockquote>TopView, one of the first serious multitasking tool for the IBM PC.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine, July 1985</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #6 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The new sale price is $99.95 instead of 149.95 <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The ZX81 represents the latest technology in microelectronics. More than 10,000 are sold every week. In fact, the ZX81 is the best selling personal computer in the world.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMIGAWORLD PREVIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to Jun Suzuki <a href="http://member.nifty.ne.jp/tarucus/museum/cool/cool.htm">web site</a></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MONROE ADVERT, FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, OCT. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Evolutiv system : Casio's answer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BAKED APPLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, October 1981<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of '<a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a>'</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Simplify your everyday life"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, NOV. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD (AUG. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/" target="_blank">Soichiro's Oga</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this U.K. advert, the Amiga 1500 was sold at £1149.99 with a colour monitor, 4 games (Battle Chess, Sim City, Populous, Battle of Britain) and the home business suite Platinium Works. <br><br> The Amiga 500 was also sold at £399.99<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pelikonepeijoonit.net">The Arctic Computer & Console Museum</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GENEVA AD, OCT. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>According to this brochure, Newbury had four models:<br><br> Model M: Main Only<br> Model MB: Main and with Batteries and display<br> Model MD: Mains only with display<br> Model MBS: Main and with Batteries and display with special low power consumption. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>''God created the world, DAI put it under CP/M''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert show the built-in user menu and system status.<br><br> The right located system is the dual-drive version.<br> The left one is the 10 MB hard-disk version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE FRONT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Description of the complete Atmos system.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the 16K static RAM expansion is more expensive than the computer itself.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert was for the Serie 5 and the ACS-8000 systems.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special Christmas offer with 12 games.<br><br> Monochrome version: <b>£199</b><br> Colour version: <b>£299</b><br></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> A computer that, for the first time, works with you rather than just for you. Hardware and Software co-ordinating perfectly, Apricot arrives complete and ready to work.<br> The MicroScreen on the keyboard, unique to Apricot, performs a variety of practical functions as a calculator, calendar, time display, and as a window on the screen. Most signifIcantly the MicroScreen prompts and assists the user by presenting simple options whilst running applications.<br> Incorporating the very latest advances in computer technology, Apricot uses 31/2" pocket-size diskettes. Secure and compact, yet offering increased storage capacity.<br> As you'd expect with a 4th generation system, Apricot offers true 16-bit processing, multi-processor architecture and 256k RAM as standard. <br><br> With Pulsar 16-bit business software and compatibility with the best selling ACT Sirius 1 and IBM PC, Apricot already has the largest available software library. <br><br> Apricot includes over £750 of software­ - SuperCalc spreadsheet, business and communications software - to ensure that your system is immediately effective. And because executives are not office bound, Apricot offers portability, a further feature aimed at improving efficiency.<br> Powerful sleek and sophisticated and all at an amazing 4th generation price.</font> </blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Video chip must be compatible with the Texas Instruments TMS 9918/A or TMS 9928/A (Japan : 60 Hz) or TMS 9929/A (Europe : 50 Hz)
computer.description:
The HB-201 was the same machine as the HB-101, but with 64 KB of available RAM memory. It was sold in grey or black case color. The 'P' means 'PAL' RGB video output.
Peter de Vroomen adds: The great thing about this computer is that it has a PAUSE button, which physically halts the CPU when pressed. Very handy for debugging or cracking programs :). The PAUSE button is that button above the cursor keys.
Also handy is the carrying handle. This computer was meant to be (somewhat) portable, so you could take it with you when you visited your friends. On the underside is a compartment that looks like a battery-compartment, but is used to store the power-cable when you are transporting the computer.
For the rest it's simply a 64KB MSX computer like the rest of them. There also seems to be no difference between the white/grey and the black version, other then the color.

emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.

Panasonic FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W|||Scanner/Printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PANASONIC FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W</strong></font><br><strong>> Scanner/Printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>The FS-IFA1 is the printer/scanner interface (left on the picture) and the FW-RSU1W is the handheld scanner (right on the picture). These expansions are for MSX2 systems.</blockquote>

Yamaha mouse #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Brand new!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>

Philips VW0020|||80-col dot-matrix printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS VW0020</strong></font><br><strong>> 80-col dot-matrix printer</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-500.<br> It was a 80-column, 50 CPS model with a 7x5 dot matrix head.<br> Commodore and Atari used same hardware basis for their MPS-801 and 1029 printers. </blockquote>

Sanyo DR-202||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANYO DR-202</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ADSS system allowed to quickly search a specific program in a cassette tape and load it. Seach time for a C60 cassette was less than 1 minute.</blockquote>

Bit-corder||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT-CORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cassete recorder dedicated to Hit-Bit MSX systems, though it could be used with any home computers.</blockquote>
